pros: Management cares about staff well-being, great co-workers, flexible hours.
cons: Low pay, no room for growth, no benefits.

job_title: Part Time Business Advisor  in Pendleton, SC
pros: good work environment, friendly coworkers
cons: Pay only once a month

pros: You pay your own retirement
cons: You pay your own retirement. Stressful environment.

job_title: IT Staff Member in Pendleton, SC
pros: Your colleagues and peers are your only saving grace. Camaraderie through mutual suffering.
cons: Churns people in and out like crazy. Top heavy with management, who are a clique. They keep getting raises every year for doing little, while you keep getting assigned more duties, and getting nothing for it. Frequent reorganizations up top instead of hiring from outside. Speaking of raises, negotiate your best salary when you start, because you'll get none for good performance. Your annual review is always weaponized against you when you ask for one. Benefits are mediocre. Stay 2-3 years to build your resume, then leave.

pros: Great place to work in higher ed.
cons: Small school. Few promotion opportunities.

job_title: Head of HVAC Department in Pendleton, SC
pros: Great place to be for working environment
cons: Pay is decent depends what you know

pros: Good colleagues (mostly) all suffer together.
cons: Incompetence is allowed and ignored. Senior management have no interest in the workers. Only look for themselves.

review_title: Ok place to start, possible stepping stone
pros: Supportive fellow employees in various areas outside my own. Bridge students are fairly good to teach to but not respectful of most instructors. Their freshmen evaluations are immature and generally poor for all faculty but they can be taught over the year to improve (book knowledge and evaluation feedback). The nontraditional students are hard working and true to their word for the most part. Gaining experience with advising and how to teach to both and what works for on line and hybrid makes this a good stepping stone for a university or other state position. Don't have to update course information or book or syllabus or tests unless you are the course director. Management has money available to update the classrooms and buildings.
cons: Pandemic stress on educators nationwide is evident here too. A lot of faculty and staff turnover lately has lost the "history" of what worked and what did not work. Arts and Sciences is trying out Assistant Deans instead of Department Chairs which is depersonalizing since that position has no time, maybe no experience for dealing with all of the instructors. Working constantly (way more than 40 hrs) and not able to have time for recharging is a problem especially when dealing with the course(s) you are in charge of as course director. Pay does not increase yearly, only when the State decides to. Occasional bonuses used to be uniformly distributed, or extra to hard workers, but now are given to whom the higher ups view as the more important ones or those given more responsibility regardless of their performance.

pros: People are friendly and will help
cons: Does not pay well especially with degree

review_title: Not What It Used To Be
pros: Autonomy for instructors is good.
cons: In the last 4-5 years, this institution has rapidly declines. Lack of support for faculty. Dishonest leadership. Shifting from an actual educational institution to a for-profit college model.

job_title: IT Service Desk in Pendleton, SC
pros: Beautiful campus, great events, cool atmosphere.
cons: Low pay for part timers, but you get opportunity for growth. Current and former part time employees can usually get an interview for a full time position if they apply.

job_title: Access Service Representative in Anderson, IN
pros: Off on 2 on Friday.
cons: If you get a supervisor boomer, you will be micromanaged to hell and back.

job_title: Student Services Coordinator in Pendleton, SC
pros: TCTC is an innovative employer that focuses on student success.
cons: Salaries do not keep up with employment trends for staff

pros: Good state benefits, enjoy working with students and faculty
cons: The salary needs to be improved.

pros: Students And being able to work with them
cons: Manage method on my girls about themselves, putting on faculty, and events in their own careers to move on to other institutions.

pros:
The state benefits are relatively good, there is some flexibility when you need time off, and some departments function well and have happy employees.
The students are wonderful and most truly want to be there to learn and better their personal situation.
Many of the employees are supportive and kind to one another and can absolutely become lifelong friends.
cons:
It is difficult to move up here. It is a small college with few positions to fill and, even when one opens up, they are more concerned with who you know than with what you know.
The upper management is only focused on bringing in money and does not care about what is best for the underprivileged students trying to improve their lives. Middle management varies by area of the college. In some departments, lower management is verbally abusive, hateful, two-faced and will always seek a scapegoat when they mess up.
Perhaps the worst part - if you go to HR seeking help, improvement, or positive change, the ultimate result is you being told by your superior's superior that your "perspective is wrong and it is his/her job to correct that." They refuse to acknowledge that lower management could be an issue despite one department consisting of 9 staff positions having lost 12 people in three years (that's right, they have had multiple people leave the same position) because the immediate supervisor is toxic and mistreats subordinates.

job_title: Financial Aid Assistant in Pendleton, SC
pros: Gain experience. Work on campus. Amazing people.
cons: You can only work at most 20 hours and cannot have another place of employment.

pros: Flexible schedule. Ok education for those who cannot afford or get into a good college.
cons:
Upper management treats college as a corporation.
lower management is incompetent and toxic.
diversity is not valued.
People with vision and valuable skill sets are leaving or being fired to keep unsophisticated morons in their positions
The "Transformative Student Experience" is a feeble attempt at culture change that is unoriginal and has little to nothing to do with the student.
A culture of "yes men."
A member of administration steals ideas and work from others to use in his dissertation.
An "Us vs Them" mentality from the administration.
The Marketing Department is quite possibly misappropriating state funds.
"Death by Committee" is the rule of law. 
No advancement, management plays favorites.

review_title: Don't expect to rise through the ranks
pros: Flexibility and for the most part, good students to teach. Great way to earn extra income.
cons: Don't expect much for upper management.  Department Heads and Deans are not very helpful and quick to blame you for problems, not the students.  Students are their revenue source, instructors are expendable.

pros: The campus is peaceful and pretty. It has a high school campus feel, but not in a bad way. It is small and near the interstate.
cons: The staff are back-stabbing, conniving, and rude.  They lie and plot against each other, gossip, and generally don't get along.  It was an extremely stressful place to work with no support from management or personnel.  Complaints about colleagues get used against you. And they will fire you without any good reason, or they will concoct a reason/force you into insanity.

pros: The state benefits are pretty good. Many of the employees are nice, but there is little teamwork throughout the organization.
cons: Some departments are organized and the staff work well together. The department that I worked in has management problems and morale problems. HR can only help if they are aware, and the problems in this particular department are somehow hidden. Well, they at least have a clue about it now. Hopefully, HR can help this department manager improve his/her management skills.

pros: Work here if you need money and have no choice; otherwise, get a job any other place that you can. Tri-County treats all its employees and students like red-headed step-children. You will not be an exception.
cons: Uncaring, incompetent management. Zero perks and management plays favorites. We supposedly "earn" sick leave but there is no practical way to use it, so management just keeps that money. Corrupt, incompetent leadership.

pros: I really liked the people I worked with. It was an easy job and management was really nice.
cons: The pay really sucked but you don't really do anything so you can't really complain about it.

pros: Flexible scheduling.  Some really good faculty members.
cons: Very little academic freedom.  No faculty union.  Low salary.  Poor quality of students.  Facilities are old.

pros: I loved my boss, i got to work on a lot of projects and got to interact with the students
cons: No cons really. I liked my job
